section.title: osquery: Collect and parse osquery result logs
section.para: The osquery application allows you to ask questions about your machine using an SQL-like language. For example, you can query running processes, logged in users, installed packages and syslog messages as well. You can make queries on demand, and also schedule them to run regularly.

The osquery() source of &abbrev; allows you read the results of periodical osquery queries (from the /var/log/osquery/osqueryd.results.log file) and automatically parse the messages (if you want to use &abbrev; to send log messages to osquery, read this blogpost). For example, you can:

listitem.para: Create filters from the fields of the messages.
Limit which fields to store, or create additional fields (combine multiple fields into one filed, and so on).
Send the messages to a central location, for example, to Elasticsearch, directly from &abbrev;.

section.para: The &abbrev; application automatically adds the .osquery. prefix to the name of the fields the extracted from the message.
The osquery() source is available in &abbrev; version 3.10 and later.

listitem.para: To use the osquery() driver, the scl.conf file must be included in your &abbrev; configuration:
&abbrev; must be compiled with JSON-support enabled.

section.para: The osquery() driver is actually a reusable configuration snippet configured to read the osquery log file using the file() driver, and process its JSON contents. For details on using or writing such configuration snippets, see . You can find the source of this configuration snippet on GitHub.

simplesect.title: file()
simplesect.para: Description: The log file of osquery that stores the results of periodic queries. The &abbrev; application reads the messages from this file.
